subj-group.subject: Review of a Large Clinical Series

title-group.article-title: Predictors and Outcomes of Pneumonia in Patients With Spontaneous Intracerebral Hemorrhage

article-meta.aff: 1Saint Michael's Medical Center, Department of Pulmonary Medicine, Seton Hall University School of Health and Medical Sciences, Newark, NJ, USA
2New Jersey Neuroscience Institute, John F.Kennedy Medical Center, Edison, NJ, USA
3Department of Internal Medicine, Saint Michael's Medical Center, Newark, NJ, USA

author-notes.corresp: Mohammad Alsumrain, Department of Pulmonary, 111 Central Avenue, Saint Michael’s Medical Center, Newark, NJ 07102, USA. Email: alsumrain@yahoo.com

sec.title: Objectives.
sec.p: Pneumonia is an important complication of spontaneous intracerebral hemorrhage (sICH). The purpose of this study was to determine the predictors and outcomes of the development of pneumonia in patients with sICH.

sec.title: Methods.
sec.p: In total, 290 consecutive patients with sICH admitted within 24 hours of stroke onset were investigated in a single center, retrospective study from January 2006 to July 2009. Clinical, biochemical, and imaging variables were registered. Stroke severity and functional outcomes were evaluated with the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) and modified Rankin Scale (mRS). Baseline variables that predicted pneumonia were investigated and outcomes were assessed.

sec.title: Results.
sec.p: The association of our primary exposure variables, such as mechanical ventilation, tube feeding, dysphagia, and tracheostomy, with pneumonia was highly significant (P < .0001, for each variable). For mechanical ventilation, we observed an odds ratio (OR; 95% confidence interval [CI]) of 9.42 (4.24-20.9); for tube feeding, OR = 22.3 (8.91-55.8); for dysphagia, OR = 13.1 (4.66-36.7); and for tracheostomy, OR = 26.8 (8.02-89.3). After adjustment of potential confounders including GCS and mRS on admission, the use of angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors, proton pump inhibitors, and H2 blockers, all the adjusted OR (ORa) remained significant. For mechanical ventilation, the minimum ORa was 3.72 (95% CI: 1.68-8.26) when adjusted for GCS. For both dysphagia and tracheostomy, mRS reduced OR to 7.46 (95% CI: 3.34-10.6) in the case of dysphagia with an ORa of 16.2 (95% CI: 4.98 to 52.8) for tracheostomy. For tube feeding, both GCS and mRS reduced ORa; the former to 14.7 (95% CI: 6.16-35.0) and the latter to 15.7 (95% CI: 6.63-37.0). Pneumonia shows a significant effect on the morbidity (P = .003), length of stay (P < .0001), and mortality (P = .041) rate of the patients.

sec.title: Conclusion.
sec.p: Mechanical ventilation, tube feeding, dysphagia, and tracheostomy are exposures associated with increased risk of the development of pneumonia in patients with sICH. Pneumonia is associated with an increase in morbidity, length of stay, and mortality among patients with sICH.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
Intracerebral hemorrhage is a common form of stroke; it accounts for one fifth of all cases. 1 Patients with ICH are generally at risk of nosocomial infection. Respiratory tract infection accounts for 30% to 60% of all infection in the intensive care unit (ICU). 2 Incidence of pneumonia in the ICU ranges 3
–8 from 10% to 60%. Chest infections such as pneumonia increase the risk of death by 3 times in patients with acute stroke and have the highest mortality rate among all medical complications after a stroke. 9

Pneumonia is an important complication of spontaneous intracerebral hemorrhage (sICH). A better understanding of the factors associated with the development of pneumonia following sICH is needed to predict which patients will benefit from early and more aggressive treatment. There is little data on the incidence of pneumonia in patients with intracerebral hemorrhage or neuro-ICU patients. In this study, we retrospectively evaluated 290 patients with spontaneous intracerebral hemorrhage. Our goal was to specify the predictors and factors associated with the development of pneumonia among this group of patients and to identify whether there is a potential relation to their outcome.

sec.title: Setting
sec.p: The study was conducted at New Jersey Neuroscience Institute, John F Kennedy Hospital in Edison, New Jersey. The protocol was approved by the Institutional Review Board of that institution.

sec.title: Protocol and Patients
sec.p: This study was a retrospective analysis of a group of patients with the diagnosis of intracerebral hemorrhage who were admitted within 24 hours of onset of stroke between 2006 and 2009. Stroke severity and functional outcomes were evaluated with the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) and modified Rankin Scale (mRS). In addition to basic demographic data, the following data were collected for each patient: the presence or absence of pneumonia (our outcome of interest) and primary exposures to mechanical ventilation at any point during the hospital course, tube feeding via nasogastric tube, dysphagia, and tracheostomy. Additionally, we collected data on the site and the type of pneumonia, length of stay, use of proton pump inhibitor (PPI), H2 blockers, use of angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor (ACE-I), and use of smoking and alcohol as potential confounders. The diagnosis of pneumonia was based on the 2007 consensus guidelines from the Infectious Diseases Society of America and the American Thoracic Society, which include, in addition to a constellation of suggestive clinical features, a demonstrable infiltrate by chest radiograph or other imaging technique, with or without supporting microbiological data. 10 Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) was considered when the patient developed pneumonia after 48 hours on the ventilator. Our institution uses VAP bundle according to the Joint Commission on Accreditation of Healthcare Organizations for the prevention of pneumonia in mechanically ventilated patients. Dysphagia was diagnosed after a standardized speech and swallow evaluation completed by a team of speech therapist. Tube feeding was started within 48 hours of hospitalization.

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: Categorical data were analyzed in contingency tables using Fisher exact test for 2 × 2 tables and chi-square test for 2 × 4 tables to examine statistical significance. Since the data were collected retrospectively, the odds ratio (OR) was used as the measure of clinical relevance. Interval data (age) were tested for normality by the D’Agostino-Pearson omnibus normality test. They were found to significantly deviate from normality; thus, the Mann-Whitney test was used to assess the statistical significance, and the age data are expressed as medians and interquartile ranges.

For hypothesis testing, α was set at .05 (2 sided), that is, P < .05 was considered statistically significant. Per protocol, baseline characteristics would be considered as potential confounders if P ≤ 5α (P < .25) between study groups, in which case the OR for the primary exposure variables (mechanical ventilation, dysphagia, tube feeding, and tracheostomy) and pneumonia would be adjusted by logistic regression. For ordinal scores (GCS and MRS), cutoffs were obtained from receiver operator characteristic curves. Calculations were made using Prism software (GraphPad Corp, San Diego, California) or SPPS analysis, except for logistic regression, which was performed using a Web-based software routine (http://www.statpages.org/logistic.html, accessed December 15, 2010).

sec.title: Patient Characteristics
sec.p: Of the 290 patients, 159 (56.5%) patients were male with a mean age of 66.6 years (standard deviation ± 16.2; Table 1). Thirty-nine (13.93%) patients developed pneumonia. We observed no significant difference between the 2 study groups with regard to age, sex, race, or comorbidities such as diabetes, hypertension, or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. However, patients exhibited statistically significant differences with regard to GCS and MRS on admission, PPI, and ACE-I use. Additionally, differences in the use of H2 blockers fell within our criterion for the consideration of this variable as a potential confounder.

caption.p: Baseline Characteristics of the Study Groups.

fn.p: Abbreviations: IQR, interquartile range; PPI, proton pump inhibitor; ACE I, angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors; GCS, Glasgow Coma Scale; COPD, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease; mRS, modified Rankin Scale.

sec.p: In all, 93 (33.2%) patients required mechanical ventilation at one point of their disease course. Thirty patients of those who had pneumonia were on mechanical ventilation, so VAP accounted for 76.9% of all pneumonia cases. The most common site of pneumonia was the right lower lobe (41%). In 12 (30.7%) patients with pneumonia, the microorganism was identified; both Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Klebsiella pneumoniae were the most common isolated organisms. Patients who developed pneumonia had a lower GCS (mean = 9.1) and higher mRS (mean = 4) on admission compared with those without pneumonia where the mean of GCS was 12.6 and mRS was 2.77. There was an effect of pneumonia on morbidity shown by the increase in mRS by 1.07 (4-5.07) between admission and discharge in patients with pneumonia compared with 0.33 (2.77-3.1) in patients without pneumonia (P = .003). The hospital length of stay for the pneumonia group (mean = 19.56 days) was significantly higher than the no pneumonia group (mean = 9.14 days), with P <.0001. Mortality rate was higher in patients who developed pneumonia, 10 (25.6%) patients died in pneumonia group; however, in no pneumonia group, only 30 (12%) patients died (P = .041).

sec.title: Univariate analysis of exposure variables
sec.p: The association of our primary exposure variables, such as mechanical ventilation, tube feeding, dysphagia, and tracheostomy, with pneumonia was highly significant (P < .0001, for each variable, Table 2). For mechanical ventilation, we observed an OR (95% CI) of 9.42 (4.24-20.9); for tube feeding, OR = 22.3 (8.91-55.8); for dysphagia, OR = 13.1 (4.66-36.7); and for tracheostomy, OR = 26.8 (8.02-89.3).

caption.p: Univariate Associations Between Primary Risk Factors and Pneumonia.

sec.p: Of considerable interest is the effect of GCS and mRS as relevant exposures for pneumonia in patients with ICH. As shown in Table 1, both the parameters demonstrated highly significant between-group differences. At cutoffs of 2.5 for mRS (≤2 vs ≥3) and 13.5 (≤13 vs ≥14) for GCS, substantial risk of pneumonia is associated with each of these parameters. For GCS, adjusted OR (ORa) was 6.27 with 95% CI: 2.84 to 13.9 (P < .0001); for mRS, ORa = 5.18 (95% CI: 2.10-12.8).

sec.title: Multivariate Analysis of Risk Factors
sec.p: There were relatively small differences in ORa after adjusting for potential confounders (Figure 1). Most interaction terms were not significant (the exception being H2 blockers for mechanical ventilation and GCS and mRS for all but dysphagia and mechanical ventilation [for which only GCS yielded a significant interaction]). Thus, only individual potential confounders were considered in adjusting each OR.

caption.p: Multivariable analysis of association of risk factors with pneumonia. Each panel demonstrates the effect of potential confounders on the association with each primary exposure variable.

sec.p: For mechanical ventilation, the minimum ORa was 3.72 (95% CI: 1.68-8.26) when adjusted for GCS. For both dysphagia and tracheostomy, mRS reduced OR to 7.46 (95% CI: 3.34-10.6) in the case of dysphagia with an ORa of 16.2 (95% CI: 4.98-52.8) for tracheostomy. For tube feeding, both GCS and mRS reduced ORa; the former to 14.7 (95% CI: 6.16-35.0) and the latter to 15.7 (95% CI: 6.63-37.0). Thus, all potential confounders left the 4 primary exposures statistically significant after adjustment.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Pneumonia is an important complication after stroke; VAP occurs in 9% to 27% of all patients on mechanical ventilation. 11 The primary route of bacterial entry into the trachea is aspiration of oropharyngeal pathogens or leakage of bacteria around the endotracheal tube cuff. 12 Our study showed that 76.9% of patients who developed pneumonia were on mechanical ventilation. The frequent need of mechanical ventilation in patients with sICH puts them at a higher risk of pneumonia than any other group of patients. The subsequent need for tracheostomy in some patients who required prolonged use of mechanical ventilation increases the risk of pneumonia significantly. Patients with tracheostomy are at increased risk of ventilator-associated tracheobronchitis, which is usually a precursor for VAP. 13,14 The bronchial colonization of bacteria in the upper airways during the tracheostomy procedure represents a reservoir for the lower airways colonization and increases the risk of pneumonia. 15

The use of tube feeding is associated with an increased risk of pneumonia in this group of patients. The mechanisms responsible for aspiration in these patients are desensitization of the pharyngoglottal adduction reflex, loss of anatomical integrity of the esophageal sphincters, and migration of gastric bacteria upward along the tube causing colonization of the pharynx. 16

Dysphagia has been associated with an increased risk of developing pulmonary complications such as pneumonia. 17,18 Dysphagia is seen in 40% to 70% of patients who had an acute stroke. Among the patients with dysphagia after stroke, 40% to 50% aspirate. Aspiration increases the likelihood of developing pneumonia by 7-fold. 19

Martino et al confirmed that there is a high incidence of dysphagia after stroke. Patients who had dysphagia or were aspirating developed pneumonia more often than those who did not have these complications. 17 Using videofluoroscopic studies, Pikus et al demonstrated that the greater the degree of swallowing dysfunction one had, the greater the chance one had of developing pneumonia. 18

Our study also showed a significant increase in the risk of pneumonia in patients with sICH who were on PPI or H2 blockers. Many studies have proposed that an increase in gastric pH due to PPI and H2 blockers increases ones risk of developing community acquired respiratory tract infections, specifically pneumonia. There was an increased risk of acquiring pneumonia for both H2 blockers and PPIs. 20
–23 The effect is seen with the use of both PPIs and H2 blockers, so one can conclude that it is related to the acid suppression. 22 In normal gastric juice with a pH below 4, most pathogens are killed, but they survive in less acidic environments. 24 With the suppression of gastric acid, there is no defense from bacteria multiplying. There is colonization of pathogens, particularly gram-positive bacteria, from the upper gastrointestinal tract. 25,26 Aspiration of these organisms is believed to be an important mechanism in the development of nosocomial pneumonia. 27 The degree of bacterial overgrowth depends on the degree of reduction in gastric acid secretion. Therefore, bacterial overgrowth is considerably higher in patients treated with PPI compared with H2-receptor antagonist. 25

Our study showed that the use of ACE-I predisposes those with sICH to develop pneumonia. These results conflict with other studies that have shown ACE-I as beneficial for elderly patients with intracerebral hemorrhage or stroke, who are at risk of pneumonia. 27
–30 The protective effects of ACE-I have been thought to be attributed to an increase in substance P and bradykinin. 26,27 the ACE-I has different effects on racial populations which can explain the difference in the result of our study; most of the studies involving ACE-I involve only Asian population. Studies involving a general white population show no reduced hospitalization for community acquired pneumonia for patients using ACE-I. 31,32

We conclude that our primary exposure variables, such as mechanical ventilation, tube feeding, dysphagia, and tracheostomy, are strongly associated with the development of pneumonia in patients with sICH, even when potentially confounding variables are considered, such as PPI/H2 blockers and ACE-I.

Our study showed increase mortality rate (25.6%) in patients with pneumonia compared with patients (12%) without pneumonia. Patients who developed pneumonia had a lower GCS (mean = 9.1) and a higher mRS (mean = 4) on admission compared with those without pneumonia where the mean of GSC was 12.6 and mRS was 2.77. There was an effect of pneumonia on morbidity and outcome, which was assessed by the mRS; the scale describes 6 grades of disability after a stroke (grade 5 denotes severe disability and bedridden; grade 0 denotes no symptoms at all), 33 shown by the increase in mRS by 1.07 (4-5.07) between admission and discharge in patients with pneumonia compared with 0.33 (2.77-3.1) in patients without pneumonia. The hospital length of stay for the pneumonia group (mean = 19.56 days) was significantly higher than the no pneumonia group (mean = 9.14 days).

sec.title: Limitations
sec.p: As with any retrospective protocol, our study has some limitations, primarily due to existing documentation. We did not include length of time on mechanical ventilation, the use of hypothermia, and the size and location of ICH. This study was an initial investigation into an area that has not been well explored. Nevertheless, we believe that the strength of our data, preliminary though, may be a point of important association between several exposure variables and outcomes in ICH. We also recognize that the sample size, although adequate in establishing significant associations between the exposures and outcomes, was not large enough to avoid fairly broad CIs.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Mechanical ventilation, tube feeding, dysphagia, and tracheostomy are exposures associated with increased risk of the development of pneumonia in patients with sICH. These factors appear to be independently associated with pneumonia, even when potentially confounding variables are considered, such as GCS and mRS on admission and the use of PPI/H2 blockers, ACE-I. Pneumonia is associated with an increased morbidity, hospital length of stay, and mortality in patients with sICH. These data suggest the need for increased vigilance and scrupulous adherence to intensive care protocols, which are designed to reduce the occurrence of pneumonia in patients with sICH, which include education of health care personnel, active surveillance of VAP, minimizing the duration of ventilation, adherence to hand hygiene guidelines, maintaining patients in a semi-recumbent position, good oral care, and the use of strategies to decrease the contamination of equipments used for care in patients on mechanical ventilation. 34

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: The author(s) received no financial support for the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.
